name: Applications in Biological Engineering
description: Overview of the research and applications of biological engineering, such as bioprocessing, biotechnology, transport processes, biosensors, bioremediation, biological materials and biomedicine.
prerequisites: Prereq: BSC 2010 or equivalent.

name: Land and Water Resources Engineering
description: Introduces hydrology, flow through porous media, flood routing, grade control structures and erosion control.
prerequisites: Prereq: ENV 3040C or CGN 3421 or (COP 2271 and COP 2271L) and MAP 2302.

name: Physical and Rheological Properties of Biological Materials
description: Theory and use of physical and rheological properties of biological materials in agricultural engineering applications.
prerequisites: Prereq: CHM 2045 and MAC 2313 and PHY 2048.

name: Fundamentals and Applications of Biosensors
description: Provides a broad introduction to the field of biosensors, as well as an in-depth and quantitative view of biosensor design and performance analysis. Fundamental application of biosensor theory will be demonstrated, including: recognition, transduction, signal acquisition, and post processing/data analysis.
prerequisites: Prereq: MAP 2302 and BSC 2010 and CHM 2200.

name: Biological Engineering Design 2
description: Senior capstone design project.
prerequisites: Credits: 2; Prereq: senior standing (4EG), ABE 4042C and two courses in area of specialization.

name: Controlled Environment Agriculture Systems Design
description: Introduces the engineering design of controlled-environment agriculture systems, including glazing materials selection, fan-sizing for mechanical ventilation, lighting distribution, cooling system design with fan-and-pad evaporative cooling, and heating system design with hot water floor heating.
prerequisites: Prereq: MAC 1147 and 3 credits of physics.

name: Special Topics: App Life Cycle Assessmnt in BE
description: Variable subjects provide content for the study of agricultural engineering topics not offered in other courses.
prerequisites: Prereq: instructor permission.

name: Special Topics: Environmental Biotechnology
description: Variable subjects provide content for the study of agricultural engineering topics not offered in other courses.
prerequisites: Prereq: instructor permission.

name: Special Topics
description: Variable subjects provide content for the study of agricultural engineering topics not offered in other courses.
prerequisites: Prereq: instructor permission.

name: Special Topics: Advanced Robotic Systems Desig
description: Variable subjects provide content for the study of agricultural engineering topics not offered in other courses.
prerequisites: Prereq: instructor permission.

name: Work Experience in Biological Engineering
description: Work experience in the biological engineering industry with advisor approval.
prerequisites: Prereq: Advisor approval

name: Control Methods in SmartAg Systems
description: Design, analysis, simulation and programming modern control methods for applications in production agriculture, biological and food engineering, land and water resources. Students will learn theoretical concepts, application programming, and simulation techniques using classical and modern control approaches, fuzzy logic, neural networks and other intelligent learning algorithms.
prerequisites: Prereq: Elementary Differential Equations or equivalent, Physics with Calculus, Dynamics or equivalent; fluent in general programming language such as C, C++, or Visual Basic, and MATLAB; Engineering graduate student.

name: Recent Developments and Applications in Biosensors
description: Introduction to biosensors, design and performance analysis. Fundamental application of biosensor theory will be demonstrated, including recognition, transduction, signal acquisition, and post processing/data analysis.
prerequisites: Prereq: At least senior status in engineering and background in biology including biomolecules.

name: Advanced Controlled Environment Agriculture Systems Design
description: Targets engineering design of controlled environment agriculture systems, including glazing materials selection, fan sizing, lighting distribution, cooling, and heating systems design.
prerequisites: Prereq: MAC 1147 and any three-credit university-level course in physics.

sections.display: Adv Cntrl Env Ag Sys Des

name: Advanced Applied Microbial Biotechnology
description: Principles of microbial biotechnology, emphasizing the application of microorganisms for industrial processes (e.g., energy, environmental, food, pharmaceutical, and chemical).
prerequisites: Prereq: general biology and organic chemistry, or consent of instructor.

name: Advanced Heat and Mass Transfer in Biological Systems
description: Analytical and numerical technique solutions to problems of heat and mass transfer in biological systems. Emphasis on nonhomogeneous, irregularly shaped products with respiration and transpiration.
prerequisites: Prereq: COP 2271, ABE 3612C.

name: Advanced Biological Systems Modeling
description: This course serves as an advanced graduate class for continued biological modeling and covers topics such as: (1) formulating, solving analytical and numerical problems with programming, (2) dynamic biological models; (3) object-oriented design and agent-based modeling, (4) High Performance Computing and Global Sensitivity and Uncertainty Analysis.
prerequisites: Prereq: ABE 5643C.

name: Individual Work in Agricultural and Biological Engineering: INDIVIDUAL WORK
description: Special problems in agricultural engineering.

sections.note: To register for ABE 6905 with your the faculty member you are working with to complete and sign the following form: https://abe.ufl.edu/media/abeufledu/documentsx2fpdf/student-resources/ABE-AOM-Special-Topics-Indiv-Study-Enrollment-Form.pdf. After the form is signed by both you and your faculty member, please email it to dflournoy@ufl.edu.

name: Individual Work in Agricultural and Biological Engineering
description: Special problems in agricultural engineering.

After the form is signed by both you and your faculty member, please email it to dflournoy@ufl.edu.

name: Seminar
description: Preparation and presentation of reports on specialized aspects of research in agricultural engineering and agricultural operations management.

sections.note: This course can not be taken as a undergraduate student in the Combination (4+1) degree. Please see the instructions on the  https://ufl.instructure.com/courses/329150/pages/combination-degree-information.

name: Special Topics in Agricultural and Biological Engineering: Adv App Life Cyc Assess BE
description: Lectures, laboratory, and/or special projects.

description: Lectures, laboratory, and/or special projects.

name: Special Topics in Agricultural and Biological Engineering: Adv App Life Cyc Assess BE
description: Lectures, laboratory, and/or special projects.

name: Special Topics in Agricultural and Biological Engineering: Data Management in Agriculture
description: Lectures, laboratory, and/or special projects.

name: Supervised Teaching
description: Supervised Teaching

name: Supervised Teaching
description: Supervised Teaching

name: Research for Master's Thesis
description: Research for Master's Thesis

name: Nonthesis Project
description: In-depth project.

name: Applied Mathematics in Engineering and Agriculture
description: Mathematical methods, including regression analysis, graphical techniques, and analytical and numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations, relevant to engineering in agriculture and the related sciences.

name: Advanced Research
description: Research for doctoral students before admission to candidacy. Designed for students with a master's degree in the field of study or for students who have been accepted for a doctoral program. Not appropriate for students who have been admitted to candidacy.

name: Research for Doctoral Dissertation
description: Research for Doctoral Dissertation

name: The Qur'an as Literature
description: Approaches the Qur'an from a literary standpoint by examining its history, structure, style, major themes, and impact on Arabic literature, Islamic thought, and Muslim culture.
prerequisites: Prereq: ARA 1131 or ABT 3500 or REL 2000 or REL 2362 or REL 4361 or senior standing.

name: Introduction to Financial Accounting
description: Conceptual introduction to financial accounting. Emphasis is placed on wealth and income measurement and the preparation and interpretation of conventional financial statements.
prerequisites: Prereq: Sophomore standing or higher.

sections.note: This class requires online proctoring for exams. You will need a webcam and reliable, high-speed internet access for this course. For lecture recording time and location visit https://warrington.ufl.edu/undergraduate-current-students/video-lectures/.

name: Introduction to Managerial Accounting
description: Accounting for cost reporting and control. Reports, statements and analytical tools used by management.
prerequisites: Prereq: ACG 2021.

sections.note: This class requires online proctoring for exams. You will need a webcam and reliable, high-speed internet access for this course. For lecture recording time and location visit https://warrington.ufl.edu/undergraduate-current-students/video-lectures/.

name: Financial Accounting and Reporting 1
description: Covers the theoretical structure of financial accounting, required financial statements, revenue recognition, operating assets and current liabilities.
prerequisites: Prereq: (ACG 2021 and ACG 2071 with minimum grades of B) and score of 70% on the Fisher School of Accounting Financial Accounting Competency Assessment and score of 70% on the Fisher School of Accounting Managerial Competency Assessment.

name: Business Processes and Accounting Information System
description: Examination of the accounting information systems in a business organization. Coverage extends over topics such as business processes, internal controls, and the fundamentals of accounting information systems analysis, design, implementation and control.
prerequisites:
Prereq: (ACG 2021 and ACG 2071 with minimum grades of B) and (CGS 2531 or ISM
3013).

name: Professional Speakers Series
description: To expose students to technical topics and emerging issues in accounting, business and related professions such as law. The course addresses career opportunities in the practice of public accounting, industry, financial services, government, and in business more generally.

name: Financial Accounting and Reporting 2
description: Continuation of ACG 3101 and includes coverage of accounting for investments, non-current liabilities and equities, accounting for income taxes, derivatives, accounting changes, statement of cash flows and earnings per share.
prerequisites: Prereq: ACG 3101 with minimum grade of C and FIN 3403.

name: Cost and Managerial Accounting
description: Extends cost and managerial coverage beyond that covered in ACG 2071. Topics include quantitative cost estimation, standard costing, flexible budgets, inventory management, pricing decisions, balanced scorecard, costs of quality, capital budgeting, transfer pricing and performance evaluations.
prerequisites:
Prereq: (ACG 3101 and ACG 3401 with minimum grades of C) and QMB 3250 and (MAC
2234 or MAC 2312).

name: Introduction to Auditing
description: Introduces the basic concepts, principles and environment of financial statement auditing. The course emphasizes the audit decision-making process, researching audit standards, audit planning, evidence evaluation, audit reports, ethics and legal liability.
prerequisites: Prereq: ACG 4111 and ACG 4341 with minimum grades of C and AC classification.

name: Financial Accounting
description: Introduction for prospective managers. Primary emphasis on financial reporting and analysis.

name: Managerial Accounting
description: Introduction for prospective managers. Primary emphasis on management control systems.
prerequisites: Prereq: ACG 5005.

name: Advanced Accounting
description: Reporting of business combinations, equity method of accounting for investments in stocks, and issues concerning consolidated financial statements.
prerequisites: Prereq: 7AC Standing; ACG 5647 (C) and TAX 5027 (C)

sections.note: This class is in Module 3.  Classes meet from January 8 – February 23.  Final Exam week is February 26 – March 1.
This class is in Module 3.  Classes meet from January 8 – February 23.  Final Exam week is February 26 – March 1.

name: Auditing I
description: Concepts and theory underlying the audit of third party assertions. Coverage includes the audit environment, risk assessment, evidential search and evaluation, internal controls, audit programs and audit reporting.
prerequisites: Prereq: (ACG 4111 and ACG 4341 with minimum grades of C, senior standing or higher, accounting major) OR (Master of Science in Information Systems and Operations Management student, Auditing Minor student, and ACG 5075 with minimum grade of C).

sections.note: This class is in Module 3.  Classes meet from January 8 – February 23.  Final Exam week is February 26 – March 1.

name: Auditing II
description: Second of a two course sequence. Applies the concepts and theory of auditing to gain assurance about key business processes and financial statement assertions. Coverage includes: audit sampling, revenue process, acquisition process, human resource management process, inventory management, resource management processes; completion activities, audit reports and subsequent events.
prerequisites: Prereq: (ACG 5637 or ACG 4632 with minimum grades of C, senior standing or higher, accounting major) OR (Master of Science in Information Systems and Operations Management student, Auditing Minor student, ACG 5637 with minimum grade of C).

sections.note: This class is in Module 4.  Classes meet from March 4 – April 26.  Final Exam week is April 29 – May 3.

name: Accounting Regulation
description: Private and public sector accounting institutions and their respective professional literature. Research techniques for addressing accounting issues emphasized through case assignments.
prerequisites: Prereq: ACG 5647 (C) and Class GE 7AC.

sections.note: This class is in Module 4.  Classes meet from March 4 – April 26.  Final Exam week is April 29 – May 3.
This class is in Module 4.  Classes meet from March 4 – April 26.  Final Exam week is April 29 – May 3.

name: Accounting for Income Taxes
description: In-depth study of the financial reporting standards for the effects of income taxes on a corporation's operating results and financial position.
prerequisites: Prereq: TAX 5065 with a minimum grade of C. Graduate accounting students only

sections.note: This class is in Module 4.  Classes meet from March 4 – April 26.  Final Exam week is April 29 – May 3.

name: Accounting Theory
description: Theoretical frameworks essential to explore structure, features, and limitations of accounting and financial reporting.
prerequisites: Prereq: ACG 5815, 7AC standing.

sections.note: This class is in Module 4.  Classes meet from March 4 – April 26.  Final Exam week is April 29 – May 3.

name: Forensic Accounting
description: Analysis of contemporary forensic and investigative accounting. Topics include: fraud auditing, litigation support, valuation, cyber-crime, and other key forensic topics.
prerequisites: Prereq: (Master of Accounting Student, ACG 5647 and ACG 5226 with minimum grades of C) OR (Master of Science in Information Systems and Operations Management Student, Auditing Minor student, ACG 5647 with minimum grade of C).

sections.note: This class is in Module 4.  Classes meet from March 4 – April 26.  Final Exam week is April 29 – May 3.
This class is in Module 4.  Classes meet from March 4 – April 26.  Final Exam week is April 29 – May 3.

name: International Auditing
description: Global perspective of auditing issues including international auditing standards and corporate governance practices providing an in depth analysis of the audit of multinational companies, cross border transactions and transfer pricing within affiliated groups of companies.
prerequisites: Prereq: ACG 5647  (C) , ACG 5226 , Class GE 7, and College EQ AC

sections.note: This class is in Module 3.  Classes meet from January 8 – February 23.  Final Exam week is February 26 – March 1.

name: Data Analytics for Accounting
description: Application of data analytics techniques to accounting information. It explores how vast amounts of data and programming tools change how management uses data to attain organizational goals, obtain relevant information from public sources, identify the value of innovative ways to apply data to measure firm performance and develop models to gain knowledge from such datasets using machine learning.
prerequisites: Prereq: ACG 5226 and Master of Accounting student.

sections.note: This class is in Module 3.  Classes meet from January 8 – February 23.  Final Exam week is February 26 – March 1.
This class is in Module 3.  Classes meet from January 8 – February 23.  Final Exam week is February 26 – March 1.

name: Data Analysis Skills
description: In this course the students are introduced to archival research. The primary focus is on introducing the most commonly used datasets on WRDS (Compustat, CRSP and IBES) and learning SAS to manage and analyze these datasets.

name: Advertising Strategy
description: Overview of the strategic planning process required to develop a successful strategic, persuasive communication plan such as an advertising, integrated marketing communications, or social marketing campaign. Case studies and projects teach the skills needed to address a variety of communications management issues and engage audiences in diverse marketplaces.
prerequisites: Prereq: MAR 3023 and ADV 3008 with minimum grades of C and ADV major.

name: Principles of Advertising
description: Overview of the concepts, strategies, and tactics of modern advertising. Explores the role of advertising in society, culture, and economics, as well as the industry and its key organizations. Introduces specific practices used to develop, place, and evaluate both traditional and digital ads.
prerequisites: Prereq: Sophomore standing or higher.

name: Digital Media Sales
description: Provides a solid understanding of digital media sales and the digital environment. Student will be able to identify & explain key concepts related to sales efforts in digital and social media, implement digital and social media sales efforts, and justify integrated efforts with research, measurements and trends.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 and MAR 3023 with minimum grades of C.

name: Branding
description: Principles of branding and brand strategy; learn to think creatively and critically about strategies and tactics applied to build and manage brands with insight into diverse audiences.
prerequisites: Prereq: MAR 3023 and ADV 3008 with minimum grades of C.

name: Multicultural Advertising in the US
description: Studies multicultural communities and the process of developing advertising, promotional, and media communication tactics. Explores the methods of utilizing insights, research, and audience segmentation for developing and evaluating campaign development, while understanding the social, psychological, and cultural framework of diverse audiences.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 and MAR 3023 with minimum grades of C.

name: Health Communication
description: Overview of health communication in research, industry, and practice. Explore and better understand the role communication plays in health care delivery, health promotion, disease prevention, environmental and risk communication, media and mass communication, and technology.
prerequisites: Prereq: junior standing or higher.

prerequisites: Prereq: ACG 3101 with minimum grade of C and FIN 3403.

description: Overview of health communication in research, industry, and practice. Explore and better understand the role communication plays in health care delivery, health promotion, disease prevention, environmental and risk communication, media and mass communication, and technology.
prerequisites: Prereq: junior standing or higher.

name: Digital Insights
description: Acquiring, evaluating, and analyzing information for advertising decisions. Emphasizes understanding the scientific method, developing explicit and measurable research objectives, selecting appropriate methodologies, and analyzing data.
prerequisites: Prereq: MAR 3023 and ADV 3008 with minimum grades of C and STA 2023 and ADV major.

name: Advertising Sales
description: Principles of selling media time and space to advertisers. An overview of sales opportunities and challenges in the various advertising media. How to prepare and deliver effective sales presentations.
prerequisites: Prereq: MAR 3023 and ADV 3008 with minimum grades of C and junior standing or higher in ADV.

name: Professional Workshop in Advertising: Preparing the Pitch
description: Short-term intensive workshops in selected areas of professional development, skills, and projects. Workshops taught by professionals and often occur over three-day weekend periods. Topics change from semester to semester, with a focus on industry skills and subjects learned best from within a professional context.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 with a minimum grade of C.

name: The Agency Immersion
description: The Agency is an innovative, real-world advertising and public relations firm at UF that offers students an opportunity to build their expertise and gain experience in a hands-on environment, working directly with clients and industry professionals. Real-world work in a diverse and inclusive team environment will help you gain relevant experience, hone your skills through client feedback, gain industry access and perspective, and build a robust résumé and portfolio.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV major and sophomore standing.

name: Copywriting and Visualization
description: Application of creative strategy/concepts, copywriting and design to the creation of advertising for traditional and nontraditional media. To evaluate and present creative work, create ads for multicultural audiences.
prerequisites: Prereq: Junior College of Journalism and Communications student; minimum grades of C or better in ENC 3252, ADV 3001 and VIC 3001. Coreq: ADV 3500.

name: Media Planning
description: Provides an in-depth overview of the media planning process. Emphasizes the value of various media channels and evaluation methods to design innovative and integrated media strategies to reach and engage diverse audiences.
prerequisites: Prereq: 3JM ADV; minimum grades of C in ADV 3001 and ADV 3500.

name: Great Ideas in Marketplace Communications
description: Focuses on two aspects of strategic communications. First: creating, developing and producing advertising and promotional content for real live case studies. Second: evaluating topical issues and industry innovation in media content innovation.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 and ENC 3252 and junior standing or higher in ADV.

name: Branding and Social Media
description: The basics of developing an Integrated Marketing Communication (IMC) plan; the role the social media marketing plan plays in the IMC; learn to develop a Social Media Marketing Plan with a focus on branding; and the impact of social media on a brand.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3403 with a minimum grade of C and advertising major.

name: International and Cross Cultural Advertising
description: Major concepts and issues in international and cross cultural advertising campaign planning including primary and secondary research to assess environmental situations, setting objectives, budgeting, media, creative, ethics and social responsibility.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 with a minimum grade of C.

name: Cultural Branding
description: Explore the sources of great advertising and great branding through a series of real-world projects. Develop a process for uncovering hidden consumer wants and needs that can inform breakthrough creative solutions. Prepare to be challenged to look at the world through a new lens, to see things they have never seen before, and to expand creative and critical thinking abilities to bring meaningful branding solutions.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3403 with a minimum grade of C.

name: Advertising Portfolio I: Traditional Media Basics
description: Create concepts through hands-on experiential learning while working on typical ad agency projects. Explores all the traditional media: TV, radio, print, OOH, guerrilla, and in-store pieces.
prerequisites: Prereq: Advertising major and minimum grades of C in VIC 3001 and ADV 3001; Coreq: ADV 4101.

name: Advertising Campaigns
description: An advanced advertising course requiring the student to prepare and produce a complete general advertising campaign. Emphasis is placed on production methods, costs, research and media analysis.
prerequisites: Prereq: 4JM ADV; minimum grades of C or better in ADV 4101 and ADV 4300.

name: Sports Advertising Creative Campaigns: CREA ADV COMPETITION
description: Students create a competitive creative campaigns for a sports-related client. Students hone creative skills and learn to prepare professional pitches or presentations.
prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 3252 and ADV 3001 and ADV 3500, all with minimum grades of C.

name: Individual Problems
description: The student and instructor will choose a problem or project which provides experience in the student's major.
prerequisites: Prereq: 3JM ADV; at least 10 credits of 3000/4000-level advertising courses and department permission.

name: Advertising Undergraduate Research
description: Mentored but self-directed work enables individuals or small groups to explore an issue of interest to them and to communicate their results to others. Depending on the topic, projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3500 with a minimum grade of C.

name: Special Study in Advertising: Health Ads for Social Good
description: Variable advertising-related topics not covered in other advertising courses.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 and MAR 3023 with minimum grades of C and Advertising major of junior standing or higher.

name: Special Study in Advertising: Game-Changing Ad Ideas
description: Variable advertising-related topics not covered in other advertising courses.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 and MAR 3023 with minimum grades of C and Advertising major of junior standing or higher.

name: Special Study in Advertising: AI & Advertising
description: Variable advertising-related topics not covered in other advertising courses.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 and MAR 3023 with minimum grades of C and Advertising major of junior standing or higher.

name: Special Study in Advertising: The Craft of Visual Communicat
description: Variable advertising-related topics not covered in other advertising courses.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 and MAR 3023 with minimum grades of C and Advertising major of junior standing or higher.

name: Special Study in Advertising: ADS FOR SOCIAL GOOD
description: Variable advertising-related topics not covered in other advertising courses.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 and MAR 3023 with minimum grades of C and Advertising major of junior standing or higher.

name: Special Study in Advertising: SocialMedia & Strategy
description: Variable advertising-related topics not covered in other advertising courses.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 and MAR 3023 with minimum grades of C and Advertising major of junior standing or higher.

name: Special Study in Advertising: Fashion Advertising
description: Variable advertising-related topics not covered in other advertising courses.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 and MAR 3023 with minimum grades of C and Advertising major of junior standing or higher.

name: Advertising Internship
description: Complete an internship in advertising or related field with supervised on-the-job training. Requires 65 hours of work per credit, weekly progress reports, a summary report, and a supervisor's evaluation.
prerequisites: Prereq: (ADV 3008 and MAR 3023 and ENC 3252 and SPC 2608) or ORI 2000 with minimum grades of C and ADV major with a 2.50 minimum major GPA and department permission.

name: Advanced Advertising Internship
description: Structured internship program that is approved by the department as an immersion experience related to the field of advertising. Requires 65 hours of work per credit and submission of electronic portfolio, including a culminating project from the internship.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 and MAR 3023 and ENC 3252 with minimum grades of C and 4JM ADV major with a 2.50 minimum major GPA and department permission.

name: Advertising Portfolio II: Beyond Traditional Media
description: Portfolio II builds on Portfolio I. It is a hands-on, experiential learning course. Students create concepts and typical ad agency projects beyond traditional media and single executions. Students create integrated, experiential, digital, and shopper marketing campaigns.
prerequisites:
Prereq: ADV 4710 with a C or better and department permission and Advertising major.
Co-req: ADV 4304.

name: Advertising Portfolio III
description: Continues the development of professional-level advertising portfolios and emphasizes the mastery of strategic, creative, and conceptual thinking. Creative professionals will review portfolios. Students will also enter creative advertising-student competitions to showcase their work.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 4950 with a minimum grade of C and Advertising major and department permission.

name: Economic Issues, Food and You
description: The role of agriculture and economics: the how's and why's of their influence on food prices and the world food situation, the environment, natural resources and government policy; and economic issues, including inflation and money. (S)
prerequisites: Prereq: not for FRE majors.

name: Economics of Resource Use
description: Introduces how economists value the environment and regulations designed to protect our natural resources from overuse and degradation. (S)

name: Principles of Food and Resource Economics
description: Introduces the field of food and resource economics, the principles of economics as applied to agriculture, and the economic problems of the agricultural industry and the individual farmer. (S)
prerequisites: Prereq: MAC 2233/2311 or higher.

name: Introduction to Agricultural Computer Applications
description: Introduces computer application with specific emphasis on applications used in agricultural businesses. Specific applications include spreadsheets, databases, word processing and DOS.

name: Financial Planning for Agribusiness
description: Introduces basic financial and managerial decision-making for small agribusinesses.

sections.note: Course requires in person examination. For enrollment, please contact Danielle Shu, FRE Undergraduate Advisor

name: Principles of Agribusiness Management
description: Introduces agribusiness management principles, application of economic principles, budgeting techniques, and principles of strategy in agribusiness from management in the United States, particularly Florida. Emphasizes the financial and tax management strategies and the requirements imposed on agribusiness management by local, state and federal government regulatory agencies.

sections.note: Course requires in person examination. For enrollment, please contact Danielle Shu, FRE Undergraduate Advisor

name: Introduction to Agricultural Finance
description: Basic financial statements, investment frameworks and theories of financial intermediation as applied to agricultural firms, along with an overview of financial institutions that provide capital to agriculture.
prerequisites: Prereq: AEB 3122 or ACG 2071.

name: Agricultural Macroeconomics
description: Introduces the world economy from a macroeconomic perspective that focuses on the links that arise from international trade and capital flows in the agricultural sector.
prerequisites: Prereq: ECO 2013.

name: Agricultural and Food Marketing
description: Examines agricultural and food marketing from a system and individual firm perspective. Explores problems and issues associated with marketing functions and institutions at the industry level and with objectives and strategies of farms and agribusiness firms that market agricultural commodities and food products.
prerequisites: Prereq: AEB 3103 or AEB 2014 or ECO 2023 or ECO 2013.

sections.note: Course requires in person examination. For enrollment, please contact Danielle Shu, FRE Undergraduate Advisor”

name: Copywriting and Visualization
description: Application of creative strategy/concepts, copywriting and design to the creation of advertising for traditional and nontraditional media. To evaluate and present creative work, create ads for multicultural audiences.
prerequisites: Prereq: Junior College of Journalism and Communications student; minimum grades of C or better in ENC 3252, ADV 3001 and VIC 3001. Coreq: ADV 3500.

name: Media Planning
description: Provides an in-depth overview of the media planning process. Emphasizes the value of various media channels and evaluation methods to design innovative and integrated media strategies to reach and engage diverse audiences.
prerequisites: Prereq: 3JM ADV; minimum grades of C in ADV 3001 and ADV 3500.

name: Great Ideas in Marketplace Communications
description: Focuses on two aspects of strategic communications. First: creating, developing and producing advertising and promotional content for real live case studies. Second: evaluating topical issues and industry innovation in media content innovation.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 and ENC 3252 and junior standing or higher in ADV.

name: Branding and Social Media
description: The basics of developing an Integrated Marketing Communication (IMC) plan; the role the social media marketing plan plays in the IMC; learn to develop a Social Media Marketing Plan with a focus on branding; and the impact of social media on a brand.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3403 with a minimum grade of C and advertising major.

name: International and Cross Cultural Advertising
description: Major concepts and issues in international and cross cultural advertising campaign planning including primary and secondary research to assess environmental situations, setting objectives, budgeting, media, creative, ethics and social responsibility.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 with a minimum grade of C.

name: Cultural Branding
description: Explore the sources of great advertising and great branding through a series of real-world projects. Develop a process for uncovering hidden consumer wants and needs that can inform breakthrough creative solutions. Prepare to be challenged to look at the world through a new lens, to see things they have never seen before, and to expand creative and critical thinking abilities to bring meaningful branding solutions.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3403 with a minimum grade of C.

name: Advertising Portfolio I: Traditional Media Basics
description: Create concepts through hands-on experiential learning while working on typical ad agency projects. Explores all the traditional media: TV, radio, print, OOH, guerrilla, and in-store pieces.
prerequisites: Prereq: Advertising major and minimum grades of C in VIC 3001 and ADV 3001; Coreq: ADV 4101.

name: Advertising Campaigns
description: An advanced advertising course requiring the student to prepare and produce a complete general advertising campaign. Emphasis is placed on production methods, costs, research and media analysis.
prerequisites: Prereq: 4JM ADV; minimum grades of C or better in ADV 4101 and ADV 4300.

name: Sports Advertising Creative Campaigns: CREA ADV COMPETITION
description: Students create a competitive creative campaigns for a sports-related client. Students hone creative skills and learn to prepare professional pitches or presentations.
prerequisites: Prereq: ENC 3252 and ADV 3001 and ADV 3500, all with minimum grades of C.

name: Individual Problems
description: The student and instructor will choose a problem or project which provides experience in the student's major.
prerequisites: Prereq: 3JM ADV; at least 10 credits of 3000/4000-level advertising courses and department permission.

name: Advertising Undergraduate Research
description: Mentored but self-directed work enables individuals or small groups to explore an issue of interest to them and to communicate their results to others. Depending on the topic, projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery, or application.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3500 with a minimum grade of C.

name: Special Study in Advertising: Health Ads for Social Good
description: Variable advertising-related topics not covered in other advertising courses.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 and MAR 3023 with minimum grades of C and Advertising major of junior standing or higher.

name: Special Study in Advertising: Game-Changing Ad Ideas
description: Variable advertising-related topics not covered in other advertising courses.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 and MAR 3023 with minimum grades of C and Advertising major of junior standing or higher.

name: Special Study in Advertising: AI & Advertising
description: Variable advertising-related topics not covered in other advertising courses.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 and MAR 3023 with minimum grades of C and Advertising major of junior standing or higher.

name: Special Study in Advertising: The Craft of Visual Communicat
description: Variable advertising-related topics not covered in other advertising courses.
prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 and MAR 3023 with minimum grades of C and Advertising major of junior standing or higher.

prerequisites: Prereq: ADV 3008 and MAR 3023 with minimum grades of C and Advertising major of junior standing or higher.

prerequisites: Prereq: MAC 2233/2311 or higher.

description: Introduces computer application with specific emphasis on applications used in agricultural businesses. Specific applications include spreadsheets, databases, word processing and DOS.

name: Financial Planning for Agribusiness
description: Introduces basic financial and managerial decision-making for small agribusinesses.

sections.note: Course requires in person examination. For enrollment, please contact Danielle Shu, FRE Undergraduate Advisor

sections.note: Course requires in person examination. For enrollment, please contact Danielle Shu, FRE Undergraduate Advisor

name: Introduction to Agricultural Finance
description: Basic financial statements, investment frameworks and theories of financial intermediation as applied to agricultural firms, along with an overview of financial institutions that provide capital to agriculture.
prerequisites: Prereq: AEB 3122 or ACG 2071.

name: Agricultural Macroeconomics
description: Introduces the world economy from a macroeconomic perspective that focuses on the links that arise from international trade and capital flows in the agricultural sector.
prerequisites: Prereq: ECO 2013.

name: Agricultural and Food Marketing
description: Examines agricultural and food marketing from a system and individual firm perspective. Explores problems and issues associated with marketing functions and institutions at the industry level and with objectives and strategies of farms and agribusiness firms that market agricultural commodities and food products.
prerequisites: Prereq: AEB 3103 or AEB 2014 or ECO 2023 or ECO 2013.

sections.note: Course requires in person examination. For enrollment, please contact Danielle Shu, FRE Undergraduate Advisor”

name: Futures Markets and Risk Management in Agriculture
description: Basic elements and principles of agricultural commodity marketing with emphasis on the futures industry. Includes use of futures markets for speculating and risk management for agriculture and finance. Participation in a computerized futures trading game is required.

name: Selling Strategically
description: Introduces professional selling techniques for all products with special emphasis given to food and agricultural products, technical systems and services.

sections.note: Course requires in person examination. For enrollment, please contact Danielle Shu, FRE Undergraduate Advisor

name: Quantitative Methods in Food and Resource Economics
description: Develops understanding of finite mathematical tools used in economics and business decision making. Topics include linear equations, matrix algebra and calculus. Lectures and problems show how these tools are used to examine economic, financial and managerial problems.
prerequisites: Credits: 3; Prereq: AEB 3103 or ECO 2023, and MAC 2233 or MAC 2311.

name: Agricultural Data Analysis in Food and Resource Economics
description: Introduces analysis of agricultural data. Incorporates statistical and agricultural economic theory into the analysis of agricultural problems. Knowledge in use of spreadsheets is assumed.
prerequisites: Prereq: AEB 3103 and AEB 3510 and STA 2023.

name: Comparative World Agriculture
description: Studies the business and economic situations of the food and agriculture sector around the world. Focuses on the historical development, the current situation and the future outlook of the food and agriculture sector. (N and S)

sections.note: Course requires in person examination. For enrollment, please contact Danielle Shu, FRE Undergraduate Advisor

name: Food and Resource Economics Seminar
description: Introduces the Department of Food and Resource Economics and career opportunities for its graduates.

name: Agricultural and Natural Resource Law
description: Legal aspects of agricultural rights, responsibilities and problems. Topics include agricultural estate and income taxation, zoning and land use planning, Capper-Volstead Act, international agricultural agreements, agricultural labor and consumer protection.

name: Agricultural and Natural Resource Ethics
description: Examines the political, economic, environmental and ethical value issues involved in agricultural practices and policies, including agricultural research. (H or S) (WR)
prerequisites: Prereq: junior or senior standing.

name: Advanced Agribusiness Management
description: Integration of finance and management to solve problems faced by agricultural firms and agribusinesses. In addition to lectures, students will work in small groups to identify and to analyze case studies from agricultural and rural businesses.
prerequisites: Prereq: AEB 3103 and AEB 3144 and agribusiness major.

name: International Trade Policy in Agriculture
description: Explores the role of international trade policy in agriculture and examines the effects of trade policies on domestic and international prices, consumption, production, trade and government revenues. Addresses impact of current trade issues on the agricultural sector. (S)
prerequisites: Prereq: AEB 3103 or ECO 2023.

name: International Humanitarian Assistance
description: Emergency assistance to developing countries to minimize losses and affect recovery. Includes legal/ethical bases; program designs promoting recovery, rather than dependence; cultural issues, including gender; and technical aspects. (N and S)

name: International Development Policy
description: Studies how factors such as poverty, population, technology, resources, trade, and the environment affect the human effort to develop. Discusses the roles of the public and private sectors as well as the process of policy formulation and implementation. Emphasizes the agricultural sector and its role in the process of economic development, especially in countries where problems of hunger, demographic pressure, and poverty are pervasive.
prerequisites: Prereq: AEB 3103 or AEB 2014 or ECO 2013 or ECO 2023.

name: Contemporary Issues in Agribusiness Management
description: A capstone course utilizing economic concepts to address the interaction between the political process that legislates domestic agricultural, environmental and international trade policy, micro and macro economic principles, private business decisions taken by firms in response to public policies, and ethical considerations in developing and implementing public policy.
prerequisites: Coreq: AEB 4138 or AEB 4342.

sections.note: This course day/time is subject to change. Students will be notified if this happens.

name: Agricultural Price Analysis and Consumer Behavior
description: Quantitative measurement of factors affecting agricultural and resource prices; seasonal and cyclical fluctuations; index measures of price and quantity variables; theory and application of consumer behavior principles.
prerequisites: Prereq: AEB 3103 and AEB 3550.

name: Agribusiness and Food Marketing Management
description: Application of marketing and management principles to agribusiness and food marketing problems faced by managers. Emphasis on case problems, group projects, oral presentations and written assignments.
prerequisites: Prereq: AEB 3133 and FRE major in the agribusiness specialization.

name: International Agribusiness Marketing
description: Problems, issues, regulations, policies and procedures unique to the global agribusiness marketing of perishable and storable agricultural commodities and food products. Combines firm-level agribusiness marketing concepts with international agribusiness marketing and export management applications. (S)
prerequisites: Prereq: AEB 3300.

name: Advanced Agricultural Microeconomics
description: Rigorous training in the fundamental mathematical models underlying the basic microeconomics principles; an in-depth analysis of key microeconomics concepts including consumer and producer theory, risk and uncertainty game theory, and asymmetric information. Uses mathematical and graphical methods to help illustrate the different concepts.
prerequisites: Prereq: AEB 3550.

name: Agricultural Marketing Strategies
description: The decision-making activities necessary to launch a new agricultural product successfully. The marketing plan development for this course follows the guidelines of the National Agri-Marketing Association Marketing Competition.
prerequisites: Prereq: instructor permission.

name: Human Resources Management in Agribusiness
description: Issues involved in the strategic and effective management of human resources in agribusiness. Human resource management concepts and techniques designed to improve agribusiness organizational teamwork, productivity, performance and enterprise success. Course explores the unique aspects of labor management and includes application through use of case problems, triad and video techniques.

name: Honors Thesis Research in Food and Resource Economics: Honors Thesis Research
description: Independent research in food and resource economics leading to an honors thesis. Student will be mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.
prerequisites: Credits: 0 to 3; can be repeated with a change in content up to 6 credits. Prereq: junior standing, upper division GPA of 3.75 or higher and completed honors thesis proposal on file.

name: Full-Time Practical Work Experience in Food and Resource Economics
description: Practical work must be a new experience and related to the field of study.
prerequisites: Prereq: previous arrangement with advisor and undergraduate coordinator and dean permissions.

name: Survey of Agricultural Economics
description: Trains students to think on their feet with respect to topics in the agricultural economics discipline. While individual courses tend to focus on a particular set of skills, this course enhances the student's ability to access the range of skills they acquired in past courses.
prerequisites: Prereq: instructor permission.

name: Public Policy and the Agribusiness Firm
description: Economic policy process at national and international levels. Issues include structure of food system, food safety, and environmental impacts.

name: Food Wholesale and Retail Marketing
description: Wholesale and retail issues that exist both in U.S. and world markets, such as brand management, supermarket management, and market research.

sections.note: This section #26221 is for students admitted to and enrolled in the Online Professional Master of Agribusiness (MAB) program. MAB students UFIDs will be entered into the permission screen so that they may register themselves. All other students will register for section #26463.

This section #26463 is for students NOT admitted to and NOT enrolled in the Online Professional Master of Agribusiness (MAB) program. MAB students will register for section #26221 and their UFIDs will be entered into the permission screen so that they may register themselves.

prerequisites: Prereq: ECO 3101.

description: Econometric problem solving and determining quantitative relationships among economic variables in agriculture and related industries.
prerequisites: Prereq: AEB 3103, 4511; STA 3023.

description: Principles, issues, barriers, policies, strategies, and decisions involved in global marketing and trade of perishable and storable agricultural commodities and food products.
prerequisites: Prereq: AEB 5188.

name: Problems in Food and Resource Economics: SPECIAL TOPICS IN FRE
description: Individual study. Problems of interest to the student and agreeable to the instructor.
prerequisites: Prereq: consent of instructor.

name: Special Topics: Machine Learn App Econometrics
description: Special Topics

name: Advanced Applications in Agribusiness Experience
description: Applications of marketing, management, and finance principles to workplace station. Applications developed from approved internship.

name: Research for Master's Thesis
description: Research for Master's Thesis

name: Microeconomic Theory II
description: Continuation of Microeconomic Theory I. Theory of the firm, market theory, market failure (externalities, market power, and asymmetric information). Game theory and applications. General equilibrium theory, welfare trade theory, and agricultural trade policy.
prerequisites: Prereq: ECO 7115.

name: Macroeconomic Theory in Open Economies II
description: Essential elements of macroeconomic theory and policy in world of interdependent nations.

name: Consumer Demand and Applied Analysis
description: Theories of Consumer Behavior in Static and Dynamic Contexts; analysis of household expenditure and demand.

name: Seminar in Environmental Economics
description: Application of economic methods to problems of environmental and regional development; input-output models, cost-benefit analysis, economic valuation, and development planning.
prerequisites: Prereq: ECO 3101 or AEB 6106 or ECO 7115.

name: Econometric Methods I
description: Linear and nonlinear econometric models, serial correlation, heteroscedasticity, errors in variables, qualitative variables, specification errors, and simultaneous equation models.
prerequisites: Prereq: MAS 2103, STA 4322.

description: This course provides students the opportunity to master a variety of writing styles used in corporate and mass media settings. Emphasis is placed on mastery of writing skills. (WR)
prerequisites: Prereq: AEC 3070C and (AEC 4031 or JOU 3101) with minimum grades of C.

name: Advanced Agricultural Communication Production
description: Provides directed experience in the following areas of agricultural communication: video production, graphic design, visual composition, desktop publishing and multimedia development.
prerequisites: Prereq: AEC 3070.

name: Teaching Methods in Agricultural Education
description: Focuses on the selection and use of teaching strategies, methods/ approaches and techniques; evaluating learning; managing learning environments; and classroom management for teaching agricultural subjects in formal educational settings.
prerequisites: Prereq: AEC 4323 and AEC 4228.

sections.note: This section is for students based at a Research & Education Center (REC) only.

name: Special Methods in Teaching Agricultural Education
description: Emphasizes supervised agricultural experience programs, record keeping, and related FFA awards. Classroom management techniques, discipline and liability issues are also discussed.
prerequisites: Prereq: AEC 4202.

name: Development and Philosophy of Agricultural Education
description: Analyzes evolving concepts and philosophies of agricultural education programs by emphasizing the history, legislation, and principles underlying organization and practice.
prerequisites: Prereq: Junior or senior standing.

name: Communication and Leadership in Groups and Teams
description: Focuses on leadership and communication in groups and teams. Topics include: what makes effective groups and teams, processes of groups and teams, relationships of members, and improving group/team performance.

sections.note: This course is for students located at the Plant City REC only.

name: Global Leadership
description: Integrated, practical, and dynamic framework for students to develop global literacy and leadership competencies. (N and S)
prerequisites: Prereq: AEC 3413 or AEC 3414.

name: Curriculum and Program Planning for Agricultural Education
description: Principles and practices used in designing courses of instruction for effective teaching and total program development.

name: Individual Study
description: Topics and special problems selected from fields such as 4-H and FFA work, demonstrations, farm and home management, rural development, pre-school planning and post-school evaluation and planning.
prerequisites: Prereq: instructor permission.

name: Supervised Research in Agricultural Education and Communication
description: Firsthand, authentic research in Agricultural Education and Communication under the supervision of a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.

name: Honors Thesis Research in Agricultural Education and Communication
description: Independent research in Agricultural Education and Communication leading to an honors thesis. Student will be mentored by a faculty member. Projects may involve inquiry, design, investigation, scholarship, discovery or application.
prerequisites: Credits: 0 to 3; can be repeated with a change in content up to 6 credits. Prereq: junior standing, upper division GPA of 3.75 or higher and completed honors thesis proposal on file.

name: Agricultural Education Internship
description: Practical experience in agricultural training and development through agricultural education organizations, agribusiness and natural resources education, and/or agricultural and outreach programming.
prerequisites: Prereq: junior or senior standing; AEC or TCH major.

name: Agricultural Education Internship
description: Individual capstone internship within a school-based setting where students observe, participate in, and lead educational instruction, curricula development, assessment of school-based student learning, supervision, and assist in advising a student leadership organization.
prerequisites: Prereq: senior standing and successful completion of all three portions of the Florida Teacher Certification Examination (FTCE) - General Knowledge, Professional Education and Agriculture 6-12.

name: Comm and Lead Dev Internship
description: An individual program whereby students are apprenticed to officials to gain practical experience in agricultural organizations, industry, extension, reporting, writing, editing, photography, graphics, broadcasting, advertising or public relations.
prerequisites: Prereq: AEC 3070C with minimum grade of C and AEC 3414 with minimum grade of C, or AEC 3413 with minimum grade of C and AEC 4031 with minimum grade of C.

name: Digital Media Production in Agriculture and Natural Resources
description: This course focuses on the role of digital media production in agriculture and natural resources.

name: Agricultural and Natural Resources Media Production
description: Various agricultural media production assignments. Developing agricultural websites and publications.

name: Teaching Methods in Agricultural Education
description: Teaching methodology course that focuses on the selection and use of teaching strategies, methods/ approaches, and techniques; evaluating learning; managing learning environments; and classroom management for teaching agricultural subjects in formal educational settings.

name: Critical and Creative Thinking in Problem Solving and Decision Making
description: Creating a foundation for effective leadership practice through the analysis and development of critical and creative thinking skills and dispositions as applied to dynamic organizational and community contexts.  Contexts include agriculture, life sciences, natural resources, and related settings.

name: Leadership Development for Extension and Community Nonprofit Organizations
description: Application of concepts related to developing leaders for organizing and maintaining extension and community nonprofit organizations.

name: Special Methods in Teaching Agriculture
description: Teaching methods for active learning, critical, creative and evaluative thinking in the agricultural education classroom. Strategies for managing student behavior, utilizing instructional technology and utilizing FFA and SAE as teaching tools.

name: Program Planning in Agricultural Education
description: Principles and practices used in designing agricultural education program plans for effective and total program development.

name: Delivering Educational Programs in Agricultural Settings
description: This course will be focusing on delivering educational programs in formal and nonformal settings. Emphasis will be placed on balancing theoretical and practical development and delivery of educational programs.

name: Teacher Education in Agriculture
description: Preparing future agricultural teacher educators with the knowledge and skills needed to provide leadership in a university teacher education program. Students will investigate various models of teacher education and determine the composition of a well-developed agriculture teacher education program.

name: Methodology of Planned Change
description: Processes by which professional change agents influence the introduction, adoption, and diffusion of technological changes. Applicable to those who are responsible for bringing about change.

name: Developing and Conducting Needs Assessments in Extension Settings
description: This course is intended to help educators in the field of extension and other non-formal education organizations: (a) acquire an understanding of needs assessments from theory to practice and (b) strengthen or develop their skills in planning and conducting needs assessments within extension settings.

name: Introduction to African American Studies

name: Race and Sports in America
description: Examine race, racism, and racialization in the sporting context in order to understand many salient issues in American society such as nationalism and patriotism, capitalism, sexism, oppression, etc. See the ways sports influence racial ideologies as well as the pervasiveness of racial oppression that exists on and off the playing field.

name: Key Issues in African American and Black-Atlantic Thought
description: The leading voices of resistance and social change that have influenced African American intellectual history, black public consciousness, political action and social theory.

name: The African Diaspora
description: Overview of transnational fields of cultural contact, power and competing economic interests in which the African Diaspora developed. (WR)

name: The Wire
description: Critically examine various themes presented in the television show, The Wire. Major topics include the illegal drug trade, race and ethnicity, sexuality, public policy and politics, K-12 education, and the news media.
prerequisites: Prereq: AFA 2000.

name: Race, Religion, and Rebellion
description: Examination of the interplay of religion, race, and rebellion in the organization and execution of the various revolts, insurrections, and social movements of black people in the US from the slavery period through the Civil Rights and Black Power Eras.
prerequisites: Prereq: AFA 2000

name: History of Hip-Hop
description: Examines the blossoming of hip-hop as a musical genre and as a cultural and political youth movement from the 1970s to the present, extending from its origins in New York city to the rest of the nation and the world.
prerequisites: Prereq: AFA 2000.

name: Mentoring At-Risk Youth
description: A community service-learning course that develops mentoring and critical-thinking skills though instruction, analysis and service. (S and N) (WR)
prerequisites: Prereq: AFA 2000 or instructor permission.

description: Lectures and seminars covering selected topics of current interests in African American studies.

prerequisites: Prereq: junior or senior standing, or instructor permission.

name: Theories of Black America
description: A multi-disciplinary examination of some of the important theories and concepts used to explain Black social, political and cultural behavior in the United States for the past 150 years.
prerequisites: Prereq: AFA 2000.

name: Black Hair Politics
description: Provides a comprehensive interdisciplinary examination of the history, sociology, psychology and economics of Black hair. Students will explore the textures, styles and meanings of Black hair as they relate to identity and power in society.
prerequisites: Prereq: AFA 2000.

name: Individual Study: African Americans in Paris
description: Directed individual reading or research on topics in African American studies.
prerequisites: Prereq: director permission.

name: African American Studies Senior Integrative Seminar
description: Examination of bibliographic resources and analysis of theory, method, and special problems in the field of African American studies.

description: Selected variable topics in the history and culture of Africa.
prerequisites: Credits: 3; can be repeated with change in content up to 18 credits; Prereq: 3 credits of an AFH, AMH, ASH, EUH, LAH, or WOH course.

name: The Air Force Today
description: Introduces the United States Air Force and Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps. Topics include introduction to flight, oral and written communication techniques and an overview of military services.
prerequisites: Coreq: AFR 1120L.

name: General Military Course (GMC) Leadership Laboratory
description: Air Force customs, courtesies, drills and ceremonies; issuing military commands; instructing, directing and evaluating the preceding skills; studying the environment of an Air Force officer; and learning about areas of opportunity available to commissioned officers.
prerequisites: Coreq: AFR 1120.

name: The Evolution of USAF Air and Space Power
description: Continuation of AFR 2130 and the exploration of Air Force history, beginning with the Vietnam era and culminating with the application of air and space power in recent conflicts.
prerequisites: Coreq: AFR 2140L.

name: General Military Course (GMC) Leadership Laboratory
description: Air Force customs, courtesies, drills and ceremonies; issuing military commands; instructing, directing and evaluating the preceding skills; studying the environment of an Air Force officer; and learning about areas of opportunity available to commissioned officers.
prerequisites: Coreq: AFR 2140.

name: Air Force Leadership and Management
description: Studies leadership and quality management fundamentals, professional knowledge, Air Force doctrine, leadership ethics and communication skills required of an Air Force junior officer. Case studies examine Air Force leadership and management situations as a means of demonstrating and exercising practical application of the concepts studied.
prerequisites: Coreq: AFR 3231L.

name: Professional Officer Course (POC) Leadership Laboratory 2
description: Advanced leadership experiences planning and controlling military activities of the cadet corps, the preparation and presentation of briefings and other communications, and the interviews, guidance and information to increase cadet understanding, motivation and performance.
prerequisites: Coreq: AFR 3231.

name: Preparation for Active Duty 2
description: Examines advanced leadership ethics, officership, preparation for active duty and current issues affecting military professionalism. Continued emphasis is given to refining communication skills.
prerequisites: Coreq: AFR 4211L.

name: Professional Officer Course (POC) Leadership Laboratory 4
description: Advanced leadership experiences planning and controlling military activities of the cadet corps, the preparation and presentation of briefings and other communications, and the interviews, guidance and information to increase cadet understanding, motivation and performance.
prerequisites: Coreq: AFR 4211.

name: Culture, Health and Arts in Sub-Saharan Africa
description: Explores Sub-Saharan African cultures, health issues and belief systems related to health and the arts. Also provides a framework to better understand health and health care systems in other cultures.
prerequisites: Prereq: junior standing or 6 credits minimum from AFH 2000 or AFS 2002 or AFS 4905 or AFS 4935 or HUM 2420 or HUM 2424.

Students learn about the major theoretical debates within the discipline, the most current research topics and apply their knowledge to the comparative analysis of development in Africa and Latin America.
